content.question: A space shuttle has a mass of <math alttext="90,000 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn><mspace></mspace><mspace></mspace><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. In order to stay in a circular orbit, it must have a velocity of <math alttext="8000 meters per seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The pilot discovers that the shuttle has slowed down to <math alttext="7900 meters per seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7900</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the shuttle’s speed needs to increase. If the thrusters exert a constant force of <math alttext="50,000 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mtext>,000</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, how long do the thrusters have to exert this force in order to return the shuttle to orbital velocity?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
